name: Jollof Rice
description: Jollof rice is a popular West African dish made with rice, tomatoes, onions, and spices, often served with meat or fish.
health_benefits: Rich in carbohydrates - provides energy
Contains vitamin A - supports eye health
Source of iron - aids in preventing anemia
cultural_significance: Jollof rice is a staple at Nigerian celebrations and gatherings, symbolizing unity and festivity. There is friendly competition across West African countries about who makes the best Jollof rice.

name: Pounded Yam
description: Pounded yam is a starchy side dish made from boiled yam that is pounded until smooth and stretchy. It is often served with various soups and stews.
health_benefits: High in carbohydrates - provides energy
Low in fat - suitable for low-fat diets
Contains potassium - supports heart health
cultural_significance: Pounded yam is a staple food in Nigeria, commonly paired with soups like egusi or ogbono. It is a traditional dish at ceremonies and gatherings, representing hospitality.

name: Fufu
description: Fufu is a starchy side dish made from boiled and pounded starchy vegetables like yam, cassava, or plantains, forming a smooth, stretchy dough-like consistency.
health_benefits: High in carbohydrates - provides sustained energy
Low in fat - suitable for low-fat diets
Gluten-free - safe for celiac disease
cultural_significance: Fufu is a staple in Nigerian cuisine, often eaten with soups and stews, and is a symbol of hospitality and communal dining across West and Central Africa.

name: Suya
description: Suya is a popular Nigerian street food consisting of skewered and grilled spicy meat, typically beef or chicken, seasoned with a blend of spices including ground peanuts (yaji) and served with sliced onions and tomatoes.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle growth and repair
Rich in iron - supports blood health
Contains zinc - boosts immune function
Good source of B vitamins
cultural_significance: Suya is widely enjoyed as a street food snack or at social gatherings, especially in northern Nigeria where it originated from the Hausa people. It has gained popularity nationwide and across West Africa.

name: Moi Moi
description: Moi Moi is a traditional Nigerian steamed bean pudding made from blended black-eyed peas, peppers, onions, and spices.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Moi Moi is often served at parties, weddings, and as a side dish with rice. It is popular across Nigeria with regional variations.

name: Nigerian Pepper Soup
description: Pepper soup is a spicy, broth-based soup popular in Nigeria, made with various meats or fish and a blend of aromatic spices including African nutmeg, uziza seeds, and hot peppers.
health_benefits: High in protein - aids muscle recovery
Rich in iron - supports blood health
Contains warming spices - may boost metabolism
Low in carbohydrates
cultural_significance: Pepper soup is often served at social gatherings and as a remedy for colds and flu. There are variants across different ethnic groups, including fish pepper soup, goat meat pepper soup, and catfish pepper soup.

name: Akara
description: Akara is a popular Nigerian snack made from blended black-eyed peas, onions, and peppers, deep-fried until golden brown and crispy outside, soft inside.
health_benefits: High in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Rich in iron - supports blood health for women
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
Good source of dietary fiber
cultural_significance: Akara is commonly eaten for breakfast or as a snack, often served with pap (ogi) or custard. It is a staple in many Nigerian households and is popular during festive occasions.

name: Efo Riro
description: Efo Riro is a traditional Nigerian vegetable soup made with leafy greens, tomatoes, peppers, and often includes meats or fish for added flavor.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Efo Riro is popular in Yoruba cuisine and is often served during family gatherings and celebrations.

name: Ewa Agoyin
description: Ewa Agoyin is a Nigerian dish made from mashed black-eyed peas served with a spicy pepper sauce, popular in Lagos and often enjoyed with bread or rice.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Ewa Agoyin is commonly eaten as street food or breakfast, especially in southwestern Nigeria, and is a staple for many due to its affordability and nutritional value.

name: Okra Soup
description: Okra soup is a popular Nigerian dish made from fresh okra, often combined with meat, fish, and spices, resulting in a thick, viscous texture.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: A staple in many Nigerian households, especially in the southern regions, often served during family gatherings and celebrations.

name: Ogbono Soup
description: Ogbono soup is a Nigerian soup made from ground ogbono seeds, known for its unique slimy texture and often cooked with assorted meats, fish, and leafy vegetables.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Ogbono soup is popular across Nigeria, often enjoyed for its unique texture and flavor, and is commonly served with starchy sides like fufu or pounded yam.

name: Rice and Stew
description: Rice and stew is a staple Nigerian dish consisting of boiled rice served with a rich tomato-based stew, often containing meat or fish.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Rice and stew is a common dish in Nigerian households, often served at family gatherings and celebrations.

name: Beans and Stew
description: Beans and stew is a popular Nigerian dish made from cooked beans served with a rich tomato-based stew, often including onions, peppers, and spices.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: A staple in many Nigerian households, often enjoyed during festive occasions.

name: Eba
description: Eba is a Nigerian staple food made from garri, which is processed cassava, typically served with soups and stews.
health_benefits: Provides energy due to high carbohydrate content
Gluten-free, suitable for those with gluten intolerance
Low in fat, beneficial for weight management
cultural_significance: Eba is a staple in Nigerian cuisine, often consumed during lunch or dinner with various soups, symbolizing a traditional and communal eating experience.

name: Nigerian Fried Plantain
description: Fried plantain, known as dodo in Nigeria, is a popular dish made from ripe plantains sliced and fried until golden brown. It is often served as a side dish or snack.
health_benefits: Rich in carbohydrates - provides energy
Contains vitamin A - supports vision health
Source of iron - supports blood health
cultural_significance: Commonly enjoyed with rice dishes, stews, or as a standalone snack. Popular at parties and gatherings.

name: Nigerian Chicken Stew
description: Chicken stew is a flavorful Nigerian dish made with chicken, tomatoes, onions, and spices. It is often served with rice or yam.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains vitamin A - supports vision and immune health
cultural_significance: A staple in Nigerian households, often served during special occasions and family gatherings.

name: Nigerian Fish Stew
description: Fish stew is a flavorful Nigerian dish made with fish, tomatoes, onions, and spices, often served with rice or yam.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: A staple in many Nigerian households, often prepared for special occasions and served with rice or plantains.

name: Nigerian Bread and Eggs
description: Bread and eggs is a simple and popular breakfast dish in Nigeria, typically consisting of fried or scrambled eggs served with slices of bread.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle growth
Contains iron - beneficial for blood health
Provides calcium - supports bone health
cultural_significance: Commonly enjoyed as a quick breakfast or snack, often accompanied by tea or coffee.

name: Pap
description: Pap, also known as Ogi or Akamu, is a fermented cereal pudding made from maize, sorghum, or millet. It is a staple breakfast food in Nigeria, often served with sugar or milk.
health_benefits: Easily digestible - suitable for infants and elderly
Low in fat - supports weight management
Fermented - promotes gut health
cultural_significance: Pap is commonly consumed as a breakfast food in Nigeria and is often given to infants and the elderly due to its easy digestibility. It is also a staple during traditional ceremonies and family gatherings.

name: Ofada Rice and Ayamase
description: Ofada rice is a locally grown Nigerian rice variety, often served with Ayamase, a spicy green pepper sauce made with green bell peppers, onions, and assorted meats.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: A staple in southwestern Nigeria, often enjoyed at special occasions and gatherings.

name: Oha Soup
description: Oha soup is a traditional Igbo soup made from oha leaves, thickened with cocoyam, and often cooked with assorted meats and spices.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Oha soup is commonly enjoyed in Eastern Nigeria, especially during festive occasions and family gatherings.

name: Afang Soup
description: Afang soup is a nutritious Nigerian soup made from afang leaves (okazi), waterleaf, palm oil, and assorted meats or fish. It is known for its rich flavor and health benefits, being high in vitamins and minerals.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Afang soup is a staple in southeastern Nigeria, particularly in Cross River and Akwa Ibom states, often served during family gatherings and celebrations.

name: Edikang Ikong
description: Edikang Ikong is a rich Nigerian vegetable soup made primarily from fluted pumpkin leaves and waterleaf, often cooked with assorted meats and fish.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: A traditional dish in southeastern Nigeria, especially popular in Cross River and Akwa Ibom states, often served during family gatherings and festive occasions.

name: Banga Soup
description: Banga soup is a rich Nigerian soup made from palm nut extract, spices, and various meats or fish, known for its unique flavor and thick consistency.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in vitamin A - promotes healthy vision
Contains healthy fats - supports heart health
cultural_significance: Banga soup is commonly enjoyed in the Niger Delta region, often served during festive occasions and family gatherings.

name: Abacha
description: Abacha, also known as African salad, is a traditional dish made from fermented and dried cassava served with palm oil, onions, and various toppings like fish or meat.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Commonly enjoyed in Eastern Nigeria, especially among the Ibo people, often served at social gatherings and celebrations.

name: Ukodo
aliases: yam and goat meat pepper soup
description: Ukodo is a traditional Nigerian dish made with yam and goat meat in a spicy pepper soup broth, known for its warming qualities.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
Low in fat - supports heart health
cultural_significance: Ukodo is commonly enjoyed during the rainy season or as a remedy for colds in Nigeria.

name: Boli & Groundnut
description: Boli & Groundnut is a popular Nigerian street food consisting of grilled plantains served with groundnut (peanut) sauce. It is a flavorful and nutritious snack.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Boli & Groundnut is commonly enjoyed as a street food snack in urban areas of Nigeria, often eaten during lunch or as a quick snack.

name: Masa
description: Masa is a traditional Nigerian rice cake made from fermented rice batter, often flavored with spices and sometimes served with a spicy sauce or yogurt.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Masa is commonly enjoyed in Northern Nigeria, often as a breakfast item or snack, and is popular at social gatherings.

name: Nigerian White Rice
description: Plain white rice is a staple food in Nigeria, often served as a side dish with various soups and stews. It is typically boiled or steamed until tender.
health_benefits: Provides energy due to high carbohydrate content
Low in fat, suitable for weight management
Gluten-free, suitable for those with gluten intolerance
cultural_significance: Rice is a versatile and essential part of many Nigerian meals, commonly served during festive occasions and family gatherings.

name: Nigerian Spaghetti
description: Nigerian-style spaghetti is a popular dish made with spaghetti noodles cooked in a rich tomato sauce, often with vegetables and proteins like chicken or beef.
health_benefits: Rich in carbohydrates - provides energy
Contains protein - supports muscle growth
Source of vitamin A - supports vision health
cultural_significance: Commonly served in homes and at gatherings, often enjoyed with a side of fried plantains.

name: Indomie Noodles
description: Indomie noodles are a popular brand of instant noodles in Nigeria, known for their quick preparation and variety of flavors.
health_benefits: Quick energy source due to high carbohydrate content
Contains iron which supports blood health
Provides some protein for muscle maintenance
cultural_significance: A staple in many Nigerian households, especially among students and young adults, often consumed as a quick meal or snack.

name: Nigerian Fried Rice
description: Nigerian fried rice is a colorful dish made with parboiled rice, mixed vegetables, and spices, often served at parties and celebrations.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in carbohydrates - provides energy
Contains vitamin A - supports vision health
cultural_significance: A staple at Nigerian parties and gatherings, often served alongside jollof rice and other dishes.

name: Yam Porridge
description: Yam porridge, known as Asaro, is a creamy traditional Nigerian dish made from yam, palm oil, and spices, often enjoyed as a comfort food.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in carbohydrates - provides energy
Contains vitamin A - supports vision and immune function
cultural_significance: Commonly prepared in many Nigerian households, especially in the southwestern region, often served during family gatherings and special occasions.

name: Beans Porridge
description: Beans porridge is a traditional Nigerian dish made from cooked beans, flavored with palm oil and spices, often enhanced with vegetables.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Commonly eaten across Nigeria, especially in the southwest, often served with rice or yam.

name: Boiled Yam and Egg Sauce
description: Boiled yam and egg sauce is a popular Nigerian dish consisting of boiled yam served with a sauce made from eggs, tomatoes, onions, and spices.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Commonly enjoyed for breakfast or lunch across Nigeria, often accompanied by pepper sauce or vegetables.

name: Nigerian Oats Porridge
description: Oats porridge is a warm breakfast dish made from rolled or instant oats cooked in water or milk, often sweetened and flavored with fruits or nuts.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Commonly consumed for breakfast across Nigeria, often paired with fruits or honey for added flavor.

name: Tea and Bread
description: Tea and bread is a common breakfast or snack in Nigeria, consisting of brewed tea served with various types of bread, often accompanied by butter or margarine.
typical_portion: 1 cup of tea and 2 slices of bread (~300g)
health_benefits: Provides quick energy from carbohydrates
Source of calcium - supports bone health
Contains iron - beneficial for blood health
cultural_significance: Tea and bread is widely consumed across Nigeria, often enjoyed in homes, cafes, and roadside eateries as a quick and convenient meal.

name: Okpa
description: Okpa is a traditional Nigerian steamed pudding made from Bambara nuts, palm oil, and spices, popular in Eastern Nigeria.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Okpa is a popular street food in Eastern Nigeria, often consumed for breakfast or as a snack due to its rich protein content.

name: Zobo Drink
description: Zobo is a refreshing Nigerian drink made from dried hibiscus flowers, often flavored with pineapple, ginger, and cloves. It is rich in vitamin C and antioxidants.
health_benefits: Rich in antioxidants - supports immune health
Contains iron - beneficial for blood health
Low in calories - suitable for weight management
cultural_significance: Zobo is popular across Nigeria, especially in the North. Often consumed at social gatherings and known for its potential blood pressure benefits.

name: Kunu Aya
description: Kunu Aya is a creamy Nigerian drink made from tiger nuts, dates, and coconut, often flavored with cinnamon or vanilla. It is naturally dairy-free and rich in resistant starch fiber.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Kunu Aya is popular in Northern Nigeria, often consumed during festive occasions and as a refreshing drink in hot weather.

name: Ponmo (Kpomo)
description: Ponmo is processed cow skin, a popular protein source in Nigerian soups and stews, known for its chewy texture and high collagen content.
health_benefits: High in collagen - supports skin health
Low in fat - suitable for low-fat diets
Contains iron - supports blood health
cultural_significance: Ponmo is widely consumed across Nigeria as an affordable protein alternative, often added to soups and stews for texture and nutrition.

name: Gizdodo
description: Gizdodo is a popular Nigerian dish made from fried chicken gizzards and ripe plantains, stir-fried in a spicy tomato and pepper sauce.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains vitamin A - supports eye health
cultural_significance: Gizdodo is often served at parties and gatherings, showcasing the sweet and spicy flavors characteristic of Nigerian cuisine.

name: Boiled Eggs
description: Boiled eggs are a simple, nutritious food popular in Nigeria for breakfast or as a quick snack. They are rich in high-quality protein and essential vitamins.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle health
Rich in vitamin A - supports vision and immune function
Contains iron - essential for blood health
cultural_significance: Boiled eggs are widely consumed across Nigeria for breakfast or as a protein boost. They are often sold by street vendors and eaten with bread or pap.

name: Nigerian Grilled Chicken
description: Grilled chicken is a popular protein source in Nigeria, often marinated with local spices and grilled over charcoal.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle growth and repair
Low in fat - healthier alternative to fried options
Contains iron - supports blood health
cultural_significance: Grilled chicken is a staple at Nigerian parties, restaurants, and as street food, often enjoyed with rice dishes.

name: Nigerian Fried Chicken
description: Fried chicken is a popular fast food in Nigeria, often seasoned with local spices and deep-fried until crispy.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle growth and repair
Contains iron - aids in preventing anemia
Provides zinc - supports immune function
cultural_significance: Fried chicken is extremely popular at fast food restaurants and parties, often served during festive occasions.

name: Nigerian Grilled Tilapia
description: Grilled tilapia is a popular Nigerian dish, often grilled whole with pepper sauce and served with fried plantain. It is low in fat, high in protein, and rich in omega-3 fatty acids.
health_benefits: High in protein - supports muscle growth and repair
Rich in omega-3 fatty acids - promotes heart health
Low in fat - suitable for weight management
cultural_significance: Commonly enjoyed at local eateries and restaurants, often chosen by customers from live fish tanks ('point and kill'). It is a flavorful and healthy protein option.

name: Fried Mackerel
description: Fried mackerel is a popular Nigerian dish, known for its rich omega-3 content and quality protein, often served with rice or stews.
health_benefits: High in omega-3 fatty acids - supports heart health
Rich in protein - aids muscle repair
Contains iron - beneficial for blood health
cultural_significance: Fried mackerel is a staple in Nigerian households, often enjoyed for its affordability and nutritional value, especially during festive occasions.

name: Garden Egg
description: Garden egg is a small, round African eggplant commonly eaten raw in Nigeria as a snack or side dish. It is low in calories and rich in fiber.
health_benefits: Low in calories - aids weight management
Rich in fiber - supports digestive health
Contains antioxidants - helps regulate blood sugar
cultural_significance: Garden egg is a popular snack across Nigeria, often eaten with palm oil and salt or groundnut paste, known for its potential blood sugar regulation benefits.

name: Semovita
description: Semovita is a popular Nigerian swallow made from processed wheat, often served with soups like egusi or ogbono.
health_benefits: Provides energy - high carbohydrate content
Low in fat - suitable for low-fat diets
Contains iron - supports blood health
cultural_significance: Semovita is a staple food in Nigeria, often consumed as a lighter alternative to eba or fufu, especially during lunch or dinner.

name: Tuwo Shinkafa
description: Tuwo Shinkafa is a soft, sticky rice pudding popular in Northern Nigeria, made from mashed cooked rice.
health_benefits: Low in fat - supports heart health
Gluten-free - suitable for gluten-sensitive individuals
Provides energy - high carbohydrate content
cultural_significance: A staple in Northern Nigeria, especially among the Hausa people, often served with vegetable or groundnut-based soups.

name: Cornflakes with Milk
description: Cornflakes with milk is a popular breakfast option in Nigeria, known for its convenience and nutritional fortification.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Cornflakes with milk is often consumed by children and working professionals in Nigeria due to its quick preparation time, making it a staple in urban households.

name: Nigerian Sardines in Tomato Sauce
description: Sardines in tomato sauce are a popular affordable protein source in Nigeria, often eaten with bread, rice, or added to sauces. They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and calcium from edible bones.
health_benefits: High in omega-3 fatty acids - supports heart health
Rich in calcium - strengthens bones
Good source of protein - aids muscle repair
cultural_significance: Widely consumed across all economic classes, sardines in tomato sauce are a staple for breakfast with bread or added to stews. They are an affordable source of omega-3 and calcium.

name: Roasted Corn
description: Roasted corn is a popular Nigerian street food, grilled over charcoal and often served with coconut or pear. It is a healthy, fiber-rich snack enjoyed nationwide.
health_benefits: High in fiber - aids digestion
Rich in antioxidants - supports immune health
Low in fat - heart-friendly
cultural_significance: Roasted corn is a staple street snack in Nigeria, especially popular during the corn season. It is often sold by roadside vendors and is a nutritious, filling snack option.

name: Coconut Rice
description: Coconut rice is a flavorful Nigerian dish made by cooking rice in coconut milk with spices, known for its rich, creamy texture.
health_benefits: High in iron - supports blood health for women
Rich in plant protein - aids muscle recovery
Contains calcium - strengthens bones
cultural_significance: Coconut rice is popular at celebrations and parties in Nigeria, loved for its rich flavor and aroma.

name: Nigerian Vegetable Salad
description: A vibrant mix of cabbage, carrots, lettuce, cucumber, and boiled eggs, dressed with mayonnaise and salad cream, often served at parties alongside rice dishes.
health_benefits: High in vitamin A - supports vision and immune function
Rich in fiber - aids digestion
Low in calories - supports weight management
cultural_significance: A popular side dish at Nigerian parties and special occasions, often served with rice dishes.

name: Puff Puff
description: Puff puff is a popular Nigerian fried dough snack, made from flour, yeast, sugar, and water, then deep-fried until golden. It is soft, slightly sweet, and enjoyed warm.
health_benefits: Provides quick energy due to high carbohydrate content
Contains iron which supports blood health
Source of calcium for bone health
cultural_significance: Puff puff is a staple at Nigerian celebrations and gatherings, often enjoyed as a street food or during breakfast.
